text.0: This is the headland of sea-washed Lemnos , land untrodden by men and desolate. It was here, child bred of the man who was the noblest of the Greeks, Neoptolemus son of Achilles, that I exposed
text.1: long ago the native of Malis, Poeas’ son, on the express command of the two chieftains to do so, because his foot was all running with a gnawing disease. Neither libation nor burnt sacrifice could be attempted by us in peace, but with his wild, ill-omened cries
text.2: he filled the whole camp continually with shrieking, moaning. But what need is there to speak of that? The time is not ripe for too many words, lest he even learn that I am here, and I so waste the whole ruse whereby I think soon to take him.
text.3: Come, it is your task to serve as my ally in what remains, and to seek where in this region there is a cave with two mouths. During cold weather it provides two seats facing the sun, while in summer a breeze wafts sleep through the tunnelled chamber.
text.4: And a little below, on the left hand, perhaps, you will see water rising from a spring, if it has not failed. Go there silently, and signal to me whether he still dwells in this same place, or is to be found elsewhere, so that the rest of my plan may be explained by me, heard by you,
text.5: and sped by the joint effort of us both.
text.6: King Odysseus, the completion of the task that you set me is not far off, for I believe I see a cave like that which you have described.
text.7: Above you, or below? I do not see it.
text.8: Here, high up—and of footfalls there is not a sound.
text.9: See that he is not sheltered there asleep.
text.10: I see an empty dwelling, without occupants.
text.11: And is there no provision inside for human habitation?
text.12: There is—a bed of leaves, as if for some one who makes his lodging here.
text.13: And all else is bare? There is nothing else beneath the roof?
text.14: Just a cup of bare wood, the masterpiece of a sorry craftsman, and with it these tools for kindling.
text.15: His is the store that you describe.
text.16: Ha! Yes, and here besides are some rags drying in the sun, stained by some severe infection.
text.17: The man inhabits these regions, clearly, and is somewhere not far off. How could he go far afield when his foot is maimed by that old plague? No, he has gone out in quest of food, or of some soothing herb that he may have noted somewhere.
text.18: Send your attendant, therefore, to keep watch, lest he come upon me unawares, since he would rather take me than all the Greeks together.
text.19: The man is going, and the path will be watched. And now, if you need anything else, say so. Exit Attendant, on the spectators’ left.
text.20: Son of Achilles, you must be loyal to the goals of your mission—and not with your body alone. Should you hear some new plan unknown to you till now, you must serve it, since it is to serve that you are here.
text.22: You must cheat the mind of Philoctetes by means of a story
text.23: told as you converse with him. When he asks you who and from where you are, say that you are the son of Achilles—it is not in that detail that you will cheat him. But tell him you are sailing homeward, and have left the fleet of the Achaean warriors, after coming to hate them with unbounded hatred.
text.24: Give him this reason: when, with no other hope of taking Ilium , they had summoned you by their prayers to come from home, they judged you not worthy of the arms of Achilles, not worthy to receive them—even though you had come and were claiming them by right—but instead handed them over to Odysseus. Say what you
text.25: will of me—even the vilest of vile insults. You will not harm me at all by that. But if you fail to do as I say, you will inflict pain on all the Argives, for if that man’s bow is not seized, you can never sack the realm of Dardanus.
text.26: And learn why your intercourse with him may be free from mistrust and danger, while mine cannot. You have sailed to Troy under no oath to any man, nor under any constraint. Neither did you have any part in the earlier expedition. I, however, can deny none of these things. Accordingly, if he
text.27: perceives me while he is still master of his bow, I am dead, and you, as my comrade, will share my doom. No, the thing for which we must devise a ruse is just this: how you may steal his invincible weapons. Well I know, my son, that by nature you are not apt
text.28: to utter or contrive such treachery. Yet knowing that victory is a sweet prize to gain, steel yourself to do it. Our honesty shall be displayed another time. Now, however, give yourself to me for one brief, shameless day, and then for the rest of time
text.29: may you be called the most righteous of all humankind.
text.30: I abhor acting on advice, son of Laertes , which causes pain in the hearing. It is not in my nature to achieve anything by means of evil cunning, nor was it, as I hear, in my father’s.
text.31: But I am ready to take the man by force and without treachery, since with the use of one foot only, he will not overcome so many of us in a struggle. And yet I was sent to assist you and am reluctant to be called traitor. Still I prefer, my king,
text.32: to fail when doing what is honorable than to be victorious in a dishonorable manner.
text.33: Son of a father so noble, I, too, in my youth once had a slow tongue and an active hand. But now that I have come forth to the test, I see that the tongue, not action, is what masters everything among men.
text.34: What, then, are your orders—apart from my lying?
text.35: I command you to take Philoctetes by deceit.
text.36: And why by deceit rather than by persuasion?
text.37: He will never listen; and by force you cannot take him.
text.38: Has he strength so terrific to make him bold?
text.39: Yes, shafts inevitable, escorts of death.
text.40: Then one does not dare even approach him?
text.41: No, unless he takes the man by deceit, as I prescribe.
text.42: Then you think it brings no shame to speak what is false?
text.43: No, not if the falsehood yields deliverance.
text.44: And with what expression on his face will anyone dare mouth those lies?
text.45: When what you do promises gain, it is wrong to shrink back.
text.46: And what gain is it for me that he should come to Troy ?
text.47: His arrows alone will capture Troy .
text.48: Then I am not to be the conqueror, as you said?
text.49: Neither will you be without them, nor they without you.
text.50: It would seem, then, that we must track them down, if things stand as you say.
text.51: Know that by doing this task, you win two rewards.
text.52: What are they? If I knew, I would not refuse the deed.
text.53: You will be celebrated in the same breath as clever and as noble.
text.54: So be it! I will do it, and cast off all shame.
text.55: Do you remember, then, the story that I recommended?
text.56: Be sure of it, since once and for all I have consented.
text.57: You stay here, then, to wait for him. Meanwhile I will go away, so as not to be observed here with you,
text.58: and I will send our lookout back to your ship. And, if in my view you seem to linger at all beyond the due time, I will send that same man back again, after disguising him as the captain of a merchant-ship, so that secrecy may be on our side.
text.59: Then, son, as he tells his artful story, take whatever in his tale is from time to time helpful to you. Now I will go to the ship, leaving matters here to you. May escorting Hermes the Deceiver, lead us on, and divine Victory, Athena Polias, who saves me always! Exit Odysseus, on the spectators’ left.
text.60: I am a stranger in a strange land, Master. What must I hide, what must I reveal to a man who will be swift to suspicion? Show me the way! His skill excels all other skill, his wisdom has no equal, whose hands govern the godlike
text.61: scepter given by Zeus. To you, my son, that sovereign power has descended from the dawn of time. Therefore tell me how I must serve you.
text.62: For the present—since perhaps you wish to see the place

text.65: me to learn so that he may not come upon me unawares from somewhere. In what place does he wander, or rest? Does he plant his steps within his shelter, or abroad?
text.66: Well, here you see his home with its two portals,
text.68: And its wretched occupant, where is he gone to?

text.70: this is his means of sustenance—a wretch wretchedly shooting prey with his feathered shafts—and that no one comes near to him to heal his misery.
text.71: For my part, I pity him when I think how,
text.72: with no one to care for him, and seeing no companion’s face, but suffering eternally alone, he is plagued by fierce disease and bewildered by each need as it arises.
text.73: How, how does he endure his bitter fate? Ah, contrivances of the gods! Ah, unhappy tribes of mortals, whose life-portion exceeds due measure!
text.74: That man—inferior in no way, probably, to any man belonging to the oldest families—lies alone without companions and stripped of all life’s gifts
text.75: among the dappled or shaggy beasts. He is a man to be pitied for his torments and his hunger alike, enduring anguish that has no cure. But to his bitter cries the mountain nymph, babbling Echo, coming from afar,
text.77: No part of this is a marvel to me. God-sent—if a man such as I may judge—are both those sufferings which attacked him from savage Chryse ,
text.78: and those with which he now toils untended. Surely he toils by the plan of some god so that he may not bend against Troy the invincible arrows divine, until the time be fulfilled at which, men say,
text.79: by those arrows Troy is fated to fall.

text.83: It strikes, strikes hard on my ear, the sure sound of someone creeping along his way as if tortured. I cannot miss that grievous cry of a man hard-pressed, even from afar—its tone is too clear.
text.86: To my latest thoughts. For he is not far from his home, but nearby. And not with music of the flute, like a shepherd pasturing his flocks, does he come,—
text.87: no—but crying out a far-sounding howl as he stumbles, perhaps, from tortuous pain, or as he scans the haven unvisited by any ship. His cries are loud, and terrible.
text.89: Who can you be, and from what country, that you have put into this harborless and desolate land? What would I rightly say is your city or your ancestry? The fashion of your equipment is Greek, and most welcome to my
text.90: sight; but it would please me to hear your voices. And do not shrink from me in fear, or be frightened by my savage looks. No, pity one so wretched and so lonely, a castaway, so friendless and so miserable. Speak to me, if indeed you have come as friends.
text.91: Oh, answer! It is not right that I be disappointed by you in this request, at least, nor you by me.
text.92: Well, know first, stranger, that we are Greeks, since you desire to learn this.
text.93: O cherished sound! Ah, that I should truly be
text.94: greeted by such a man, after so long a time! What need, young man, has made you land here and brought you to this spot? What business? What wind so kind? Speak, tell me all, so that I may know who you are.
text.95: My birthplace is the island Scyros, and I am sailing
text.96: homeward. I am the son of Achilles, by name Neoptolemus. Now you know everything.
text.97: O son of a father I loved, and of soil I cherished! Ward of aged Lycomedes, on what mission have you touched this shore? From where are you sailing?
text.98: Well, since you ask, it is from Ilium that I am now guiding my ship.
text.99: What? You were certainly not our shipmate at the beginning of the expedition there.
text.100: And did you have a part in that toil?
text.101: Then you do not know who I am?
text.102: How should I know one whom I have never seen before?
text.103: Then you have not even heard my name, or any rumor of those sufferings under which I have been perishing?
text.104: Be sure that I know nothing of what you ask.
text.105: How cursed I must be, how abhorred by the gods,
text.106: if not a word of my miserable condition has reached my homeland, or any Greek land at all! Instead those men, who against the gods’ laws cast me away, keep their secret and laugh, while my plague has ever flourished and grows worse!
text.107: O my son, boy whose father was Achilles, here I am before you, the man of whom you have perhaps heard as lord of the bow of Heracles, Philoctetes the son of Poeas. I am he whom the two marshalls and the Cephallenian king
text.108: shamelessly hurled to this solitude which you see, when I was wasting with a fierce disease, stricken by the savage bite of the murderous serpent. With that plague for my sole companion, boy, those men put me out
text.109: here alone and left, after they landed here with their fleet from sea-washed Chryse . Delighted they were then, when they saw me asleep after much tossing on the waves, in the shelter of a cave upon the shore, and they abandoned me, first setting out a few rags, as though for an unfortunate beggar, and a bit of food, too—
text.110: a small work of charity. But may they get what they gave me! Can you imagine, boy, what kind of awakening I had when they had gone, and I rose from sleep that day?—what stinging tears I wept, and what miseries I bewailed when I saw that the ships with which I had sailed
text.111: were all gone, and that there was no man in the place, not one to help me, not one to ease the sickness that afflicted me, when looking all around me, I could find nothing at hand, save agony—but of that a ready store?
text.112: So time passed for me, season by season, and alone in this narrow house, I had to attend to all my wants by my own resources. For my stomach’s needs this bow provided, bringing down doves on the wing. And whatever my string-sped arrow might strike,
text.113: in pain I would crawl to it myself, dragging my wretched foot behind me. Or, again, if water had to be fetched, or, if when the frost had spread, as often happens in winter, a bit of firewood had to be broken, I would creep out in pain and
text.114: manage it. Then fire would be lacking; but by rubbing stone hard on stone I would at last reveal the hidden spark which preserves me from day to day. Indeed, a roof over my head and a fire inside provides all that I want—except release from my disease.
text.115: Come now, son, you must understand what sort of island this is. No mariner approaches it by choice, since there is no anchorage or port where he can find a gainful market or a kindly host. This is not a place to which prudent men voyage. But suppose that some one has put in against his will, for such things may often
text.116: happen in the long course of a man’s life. These visitors, then, when they come, son, have compassionate words for me, and, perhaps moved by pity, they give me a little food or some clothing.
text.117: But there is one thing that no one will do, whenever I mention it: take me home in safety. No, this is already the tenth year that I am wasted by misery from hunger and suffering, by feeding this gluttonous plague. This is what the Atreids and the forceful Odysseus have done to me, boy.
text.118: May the gods on Olympus someday give them agonies as strong in requital for mine!
text.119: I believe that I, too, pity you, son of Poeas, as much as your former visitors.
text.120: And I myself attest your accusations,
text.121: for I know their truth through my own experience with the wickedness of the Atreids and the force of Odysseus.
text.122: What, do you also have a grievance against the accursed sons of Atreus, a cause for anger at some mistreatment?
text.123: If only I might one day be allowed to fulfill my heart’s rage by the deeds of my hand,
text.124: so that Mycenae might learn, and Sparta , that Scyros also is a mother of brave men!
text.125: Well said, son! Now what is the reason that you have come complaining against them with this fierce wrath?
text.126: I will tell you—and yet it is hard to tell—
text.127: the outrage that I suffered from them upon my arrival there. For when fate decreed that Achilles should die—
text.128: Ah, me! Tell me no more, until I first know this—is the son of Peleus dead?
text.129: Dead—not by a mortal hand, but by a god’s.
text.130: He was brought down, as men say, by the arrow of Phoebus.
text.131: Well, noble alike are the slayer and the slain. But I am at a loss to know, son, whether I should first inquire into the wrong done you, or mourn the dead.
text.132: Your own sorrows, I think, are enough
text.133: for you, unhappy man, without mourning for those of your neighbor.
text.134: You speak the truth. Therefore tell me again what happened to you, and how they wronged you.
text.135: They came for me in a ship elaborately ornamented, shining Odysseus, and he who fostered my father,
text.136:
and said—whether truly or falsely, I do not know—that since my father had perished, fate now forbade that anyone but I should take the towers of Troy . 
 Saying that this, my friend, was how things stood, they caused me no long delay before I set sail in haste,
text.137:
chiefly because of my yearning for the dead, that I might look upon him before burial, since I had never seen him. Then, besides, theirs was a fine promise, if by accompanying them I might sack the towers of Troy .
 It was now the second day of my voyage
text.138:
when, sped by breeze and oar, I approached bitter Sigeum. When I landed, straightaway the entire army thronged around me with greetings, vowing that they saw their lost Achilles once more alive. 
 He, though, lay ready for burial, and I, unhappy,
text.139: when I had wept for him, went before long to the Atreids, to friends, as it was reasonable to suppose,—and claimed my father’s arms and all else that had been his. O, their reply was bold and shameless! Seed of Achilles, you may take all else that was your father’s. But of those arms another man now is lord, the son of Laertes .
text.140: The tears came quick to my eyes as I sprang up in passionate anger and said in my bitterness, Madman! Have you dared give my arms to another man in my place, without asking me? But Odysseus—for he chanced to be at hand—said, Yes, boy, they awarded them as was just, since it was I who saved the arms and their master by my presence at the crucial moment. Then immediately, in my fury, I began to lash at him with every kind of insult
text.141: and left not one unsaid, if he was indeed to rob me of my arms. At this point, stung by the abuse, though not given to anger, he answered,— You have not gone to where we have; instead you have been absent from where you were needed. And since your tongue is so arrogant, you will never sail back to Scyros with those arms in your possession. In that way rebuked, in that way insulted, I sail for home, deprived of what is my own by that worst offspring of a wicked line, Odysseus.
text.142: And yet I do not blame him as much as I do those in power. For a city hangs wholly on its leaders, and so does an army, but when men shatter law and order, it is the lessons of their teachers that corrupt them. My tale is told in full. May he who hates the Atreids
text.143: be as dear to the gods as he is to me!

text.146: to the son of Laertes . Hear it, blessed queen, who rides on bull-slaughtering lions!
text.147: It seems that you have come to me, friends, well commended by a grief that matches my own.
text.148: Your story is in harmony with mine, so that I can recognize the work of the Atreids and of Odysseus. For well I know that he would put his tongue to any base tale and to any mischief-making, if thereby he could hope to accomplish something criminal in the end.

text.197: Son of Achilles, I asked my companion here, when he was guarding your ship with two others, to tell me where you might be found,
text.198: since I have chanced upon you unexpectedly by the good fortune of coming to anchor off this very coast. With no great company I am homeward bound on my trader’s voyage from Ilium to Peparethus with its cluster-laden vines, but when I heard that the sailors
